Description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Experian and its subsidiaries for deceiving consumers about the use of credit scores it sold to consumers. The CFPB said that Experian claimed the credit scores it marketed and provided to consumers were used by lenders to make credit decisions. In fact, lenders did not use Experian's scores to make those decisions. The CFPB ordered Experian to truthfully represent how its credit scores are used. Experian was required to pay a civil penalty of $3 million.

Three national consumer reporting agencies agreed to a total of $2.5 million in payments as part of settlements of allegations that they each violated provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act by failing to maintain a toll-free telephone number with personnel accessible to consumers during normal business hours.

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Private Litigation Case Title: Holman v. Experian Information Solutions, Inc. et al

Description: Experian, TransUnion, and Equifax agreed to pay a total of $7.175 million to settle allegations they engaged in deceptive marketing activities by signing up customers to credit monitoring services they were unaware of, and also produced credit reports that failed to properly verify information and did not take into account Mississippi law. The announcement did not indicate how much each company would pay. Here we assume the total was divided equally among the three.

Equifax Information Services, Experian Information Solutions and TransUnion agreed to pay a total of $6 million to settle multistate allegations relating to their handling of consumer disputes about credit report errors, monitoring and disciplining data furnishers (providers of credit reporting information), accuracy in consumer credit reports, and the marketing of credit monitoring products to consumers who call the credit reporting agencies to dispute information on their credit report. The settlement did not specify how the $6 million cost would be split among the three companies; we assume each paid $2 million.
